conclusion: The graph shows displacement x (in meters) as a function of time t (in seconds).
Initial displacement at t = 0 is approximately 10 m.
At t â‰ˆ 2.5 s, the displacement becomes 0.
By t = 4 s, the displacement reaches approximately -10 m.
For a displacement-time graph, the slope represents velocity (v = dx/dt).
When the curve has a positive slope: moving in the positive direction.
When the curve has a negative slope: moving in the negative direction.
When the curve is horizontal: momentarily at rest.

premise: The curve has a negative slope from 0 to ~2.5 seconds.
conclusion: The particle moves in the negative direction (velocity is negative) from 0 to ~2.5 seconds.

premise: At ~2.5 seconds, the particle passes through the origin (x = 0).
conclusion: The particle passes through the origin (x = 0) at approximately t = 2.5 seconds.

premise: The curve continues with a negative slope from ~2.5 to 4 seconds.
conclusion: The particle continues moving in the negative direction from ~2.5 to 4 seconds.
Speed is the magnitude of velocity. So we need to find when |v| = 5 m/s.

premise: Velocity v = slope of the displacement-time curve.
conclusion: To find when the speed is 5 m/s, identify points where the slope equals either +5 or -5.
Initially, the slope is negative and gradually increasing in magnitude (steeper downward).
Later, the slope begins to level off as the curve approaches -10 m.

premise: The slope appears to pass through -5 m/s at two points: once during the early part of the motion and once during the later part.
conclusion: The particle's speed equals 5 m/s at approximately two moments within the 0-4 second interval, both times with a negative velocity.
